let's get into the economic collapse

points and everyone is looking at this
you know saying wow look how quickly
that drop we also see the cryptocurrency
market where Bitcoin dropped quite
quickly also now the thing is when the
crash hits when everything starts to
fall apart it's going to come down very
very fast and people aren't going to
know what's going on yes it looks great
when it's being pushed up
everyone thinks that it could never end
but all of a sudden with a snap of a
finger things can change and this is a
warning to everyone that things can
change very very rapidly now this was a
very tiny small drop but just coming
down 660 points there was 68 point five
billion that was lost to the very very
wealthy and yes is this a lot of money
no but what we can see is when the
market comes down and it comes down hard
and those people who aren't in the
inside who are shorting the market
they're gonna lose a lot of money now a
lot of people out there say well I don't
really care I'm not in the market it
doesn't affect me there's I don't care
if it goes up I don't care if it goes
down but for those people who are
working in companies
the stock market reflects how the
company is doing and allows the company
to continue on the way it is even though
it's illusionary when the market comes
down it gives corporations an excuse to
start laying off people to shut plants
to shut certain departments down and
this is what corporations use to what
they call restructure or to minimize
costs and things like that so even
though you're not invested in the stock
market this is a way where it's the end
of the economic cycle where the stock
market is the Flair that is shot up into
the sky to let everyone know because
everyone follows the stock market that
the economy has turned down even though
the economy has turned down way way
before this it allows the companies the
excuse to start laying off people and
even though you're not invested in the
market guess what you could lose your
job plants can close pensions declined
there's a lot that goes on with this and
this is why they keep the market up up
to a certain point and then they're able
to drop it at a certain point because
they can affect a lot of different areas
and allow corporations to restructure
cut their costs because they know it's
one gigantic illusion and even maybe
have bailouts and we've seen this in the
past now what's very interesting about
all of this is that this is looking very
much like 2008 and we have to say that
Friday's market plunge marked the start
of the next crash economic and market
conditions are very very similar
to late 2007 early 2008 remember back
then everything was going great home
prices were soaring jobs were plentiful
the great cultural marketing machine was
busy proclaiming that new era permanent
prosperity had gone thanks to the steady
leadership of Alan Greenspan and then
Ben Bernanke and of course the financial
crisis arrived in late 2008 even though
prior to 2008 that crash when it came in
October they were telling us they
weren't forecasting a recession
everything is contained
there's no problems housing does not go
down everything was great and they were
raising the rates all throughout this
period of time and they realized when
they hit a certain area things started
to fall apart so they dropped the rates
and ben bernanke drop interest rates to
1% this provided an unprecedented
incentive for investors institutions to
borrow igniting a massive housing bubble
as well as an outsized equity and bond
gains they did this on purpose and this
is coming from Chris Martenson from Peak
prosperity saying that this is very
similar to what happened in 2008
now it's worth taking a moment to
understand the mechanism the Federal
Reserve used back then to lower interest
rates it did so by flooding the banking
system with enough liquidity and of
course this is done through
electronically printed digital currency
units until all the banks felt
comfortable lending or borrowing from
each other at an average rate of about
1% the knock-on effect of flooding the
US banking system in this way creating
an echo bubble to replace the one
created early during an Alan Greenspan
tenure known as the dot-com bubble now
when we look at this we can see how they
have created their bubbles because we
could see this huge surge and it reaches
the top and then everything drops off
again we saw that back in the dot-com
era then we saw the echo bubble and here
we are where where twice as high as we
were from the other prior two bubbles
and it tells us something is going on
here and we know what's going on here
it's one gigantic illusion now the
warning signs in 2007 were abundant and
for most completely obvious in hindsight
again when you're in 2007 in 2008
you're really not seeing it because
again you're here in the corporate media
you're here in the central bank and
everyone thinks that this is going to
continue on forever and when we look
back we see that yes there were many
many signs and there are many peril
features
that we see today - going back to
2007-2008 now in 2007 people were
borrowing heavily against their rising
home prices today we have record
household debt record auto loan balances
record corporate debt and a record
sovereign bomb debt in 2007 the Fed was
carefully raising the rates to see if
they could build up an interest rate
buffer today we also have rising rates
and declining market liquidity due to
reduced central bank QE activity now the
raising rates today it's not exactly the
same as it was in 2007 now unlike the
mechanism the Fed used in 2007 today
it's not driving interest rates higher
by withdrawing liquidity instead it's
doing so by simply offering a rate of
interest to banks on their excess
reserves and that drags the overall rate
of interest up why because if you're a
bank and you have the choice between
either lending overnight to another bank
or lending money to the Fed then you're
going to take the best deal right now
the Fed is offering a pretty darn sweet
deal and we can see this with the chart
we can see that interest rates on excess
reserves are moving up and if we go back
it was around point zero four and today
in 2018 it's around 1.5 now without this
little feature and by the way this was
authorized by Congress back in 2008 the
Fed would have to drain many hundreds of
billions of dollars from their system to
hike interest as instead now they can
just set the interest to banks on their
excess reserves higher as if it were
magic dial that sets the price of money
it's pretty darn cool trick but its
newness prevents us from looking to past
interest hiking cycles for clues as to
how this current one will play out
because the dynamics are totally
different now the Fed is starting to
drain liquidity from the system it's
using a process
whereas reducing its balance sheet on
that front we see that the Fed has
allowed some 30 billion of Treasuries to
roll over on its balance sheets this
simply means that when these instrument
instruments mature the Treasury
Department returned the principal to the
Fed instead of seeing the Fed replaced
the bonds by printing up more money to
buy more of the same securities at the
next treasury auction so here we are
nine years into the recovery and the
central bank's printed the largest
amount of emergency money ever so are we
still experiencing an emergency of
historically unprecedented magnitude or
are we years into a joying
a robust recovery as the corporate media
is trying to convince us of as the Fed
is trying to convince us of which is it
well the markets cannot withstand any

when that occurs all the central bank's

remaining purchase power of the world's

happens what needs to happen first well
the markets need to fall very very hard
this will allow the central banks enough

and we're probably going to see that Dow

we're gonna see this happen more often
and once again this could be the
